description: The 4-Hypercube, or the Tesseract, is a four-dimensional analog of the cube and part of the hypercube family. Composed of eight cubic cells, it has 16 vertices, 32 edges, and 24 square faces, challenging our three-dimensional intuition. This complexity makes it a subject of interest in mathematics, art, and literature, symbolizing the mysteries and possibilities of higher-dimensional spaces. The tesseract’s representation of the fourth dimension continues to inspire wonder about dimensions beyond our own.

The 4-Sphere, also known as the hypersphere or glome, is the four-dimensional analog of a sphere. It consists of all points equidistant from a central point in four-dimensional space. With 4D volume and surface area properties that extend those of a 3D sphere, the 4-sphere challenges our ability to visualize higher dimensions. Its elegant symmetry and properties make it a key object of study in higher-dimensional geometry and theoretical physics.

The 4-Simplex, or 5-cell, is the simplest possible convex regular 4-polytope, the four-dimensional analog of a tetrahedron. Composed of 5 tetrahedral cells, it has 5 vertices, 10 edges, and 10 triangular faces. The 4-simplex's geometric simplicity and symmetry make it fundamental in the study of higher-dimensional spaces and in various mathematical fields, including topology and geometry.

The 4-Torus, or the spherical torus, is a four-dimensional object that generalizes the concept of a torus to higher dimensions. It can be thought of as a Cartesian product of two 2-spheres. The 4-torus's complex structure, involving intricate relationships between its components, is significant in various branches of mathematics, including topology and algebraic geometry, and finds applications in theoretical physics, particularly in string theory.

The 4-Orthoplex, also known as the 16-cell, is a four-dimensional analog of the octahedron. Consisting of 16 tetrahedral cells, it has 8 vertices, 24 edges, and 32 triangular faces. The orthoplex’s high degree of symmetry and unique structure make it an important shape in higher-dimensional geometry and in studies of polytopes. Its dual relationship with the 4-hypercube is of particular interest in mathematical research.
